attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
It was noted that there were zero or minimal variations between the physical and the book stocks in most items except

v  White ingredients were 9kgs less by 1 Bag.

v  Poly bags had cumulative variance of +3,726 pieces

v  Bread stock had a short fall of -5 loaves.

v  Other stock items had nil or minimal variations

It was also noted that the physical crate counted were less than book balance by 180 crates. Route crates balance at the time of audit was 469 crates.  

The table below illustrates the findings.

During the stock take it was found that the branch didn’t fully meet the orders of that day, 1,878 loaves were ordered but not supplied. Therefore, the total quantity not supplied was deducted from the physical stock counted. The table below illustrates the findings: -
attributes.recommendation:
Branch management needs to check on positive variation on poly bags and establish the root cause.

Crates route balance needs to be reduced to zero as per the company policy.

The operations department needs to resolve the issue of 180 crates and balance be adjusted.

The branch needs to plan adequately to fulfil all orders and to avoid loss of revenue also orders not supplied can be used to cover up bread short fall in the branch. Therefore, the branch should invoice as per the bread availability.
attributes.effect:
Variations in white ingredients and poly bags are significant, and this indicates a weakness on the stock controls.

Crates’ Balance are high and if not close monitored can lead to loss of the company assets.

Failing to fulfil market demand results in loss of revenue.

value:
We will tighten stock control to ensure minimal variation.

We will improve accuracy by recording damaged poly bags to curb variances noted in future.

We will do follow-up with the sales team to reduce crate balances.

Un – delivered orders were caused by oven breakdown MBN 191.

Inventory should be controlled by doing a periodical Stock count check.

The ingredient bag was recovered from the responsible Supervisor.

Good Issue of polybag was irrespective with Physical.

We are taking follow up for   -180 less crates.

Bread stocks control to be maintained.

In a prior report dated 7th March 2025, it was noted that the physical stock counted compared to SAP warehouse balances revealed that bread had -44.25 loaves while polybags had +1,658 pcs. The rest of the other stocks had immaterial variances.
Previous
A physical stock take of all items in the branch was conducted on 8 April 2025.
A weakness was noted on the internal controls as depicted by stock variations.
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to determine whether the book stock was  matching with the physical stock counted.

attributes.title: Bread Weight
attributes.description: Numerous underweights were observed at 400 Ctw & 400 grand. The table below illustrates the findings:-
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should enhance the frequency of checks at the dividing table to ensure that the dividers adhere to the dividing range and strive to ensure that they always pack loaves of the correct weight
attributes.effect: Presence of underweights is an indication of not following the laid down company guidelines on weight. The underweight should be discouraged since it may cost the company unnecessary fines due to non-compliance to laid down standards of operation as per the regulatory body (KEBS).

value: Regular weight check and follow up of production process will aid in eradicating underweight.

Production Procedure to be adhered, dividing ranges variety wise to be followed rigorously

I advise the manager to ensure the required number of tins were maintained in rotation as per production plan.

In prior audit from the samples picked, bread underweight were noted as follows; 400g CT – 7%, 400g Grande - 9%, 600g W - 17%, 600g Barrel - 11% while 800g W had 27%In prior audit from the samples picked, bread underweight were noted as follows; 400g CT – 7%, 400g Grande - 9%, 600g W - 17%, 600g Barrel - 11% while 800g W had 27%
Previous
Bread produced, packed and ready to be dispatched to market on 9th April 2025 was randomly selected and weighed.
The branch did not comply with bread weight controls and this indicated that controls were not strong enough
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to check whether bread dispatched to market  was of the correct weight as per the Weight and measures act

attributes.title: Bread Damages
attributes.description:
From the analysis, it was noted that: -

ü  The production damage was 0.28% of the total bread produced and cost implication was Ksh. 20,299.00. The calculation excludes oven damages.

ü  The market damage was 0.89% of total sales and cost implication was Ksh. 125,676.49.

The table below illustrates the findings: -

            Table 1 Analysis of Production Damages

Note: Over the audited period oven damages were 1,814 loaves and was excluded on calculation of production damages.

         Table 2 Analysis of Market Damages
attributes.recommendation:
The branch management should control damages by ensuring that all production procedures are followed and bread produced is of good quality

Implement maintenance management systems which help to proactive maintain machines on time to reduce downtime and maximize equipment performance.
attributes.effect: The production and market damage levels were above the set limits which implied unbudgeted losses/cost incurred due to excess damages

value: Production damage and market damage were contributed by frequent oven breakdown which resulted in poor quality products.

Production damage was caused by frequent oven breakdown which resulted in poor quality products

We will follow up with KAF for Preventive maintenance of oven to avoid oven damages losses.

During the prior audit it was noted that production damages were averaging at 0.45% of the production and market damages stood at 0.61% of the total sales.

There were 740 loaves oven damages
Previous
Production and market damage were reviewed for a period of 38 days from 1st March 25 to 7th April 2024
From the analysis bread damages exceeded the set limit and this indicates that branch was not following up the production procedures.
Operations/Production Department
The Production and market damages were analyzed to establish whether they were within the set limit of 0.20% and 0.50%  respectively.

attributes.title: Damages sent to Ingredients’ Balance Analysis
attributes.description:
It was observed that there was a significant difference between total damage at the branch level and damage sent to ingredients damage. Total branch damage was 9,112.90 pieces while those sent to ingredients were 8,657.50 pieces, this implies that damages sent were less by 412.40 loaves.

Below is a summary of the findings: -
attributes.recommendation: Branch management to put measures in place to weigh and verify daily damage broken and sent to ingredients to reflect accurate status of declared and available damages.Branch management to put measures in place to weigh and verify daily damage broken and sent to ingredients to reflect accurate status of declared and available damages.
attributes.effect:
Negative variation indicates that the branch was overstating damage.

Excess damage indicates a poor recording of bread produced or market returns.

Excess damage is a revenue loss for the company because bread could not be counted on bread stock.

value: To improve accuracy in recording to minimize variation.
Managers advised to do proper recording of damages to avoid any variations. Appropriate control measures need to be enhanced
N/A
Bread damage sent to ingredients were computed to establish whether damages sent match with damages captured on the SAP systems. The audit period was from 1st March 2025 to 9th April 2025
it was observed that controls were not strong enough therefore branch needs to improve on maintaining accurate data.
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to determine if the damages posted on the SAP systems were matching with damages sent to ingredients department.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
Below is a summary of the findings.

v  Utto consumption stood at 100 %.

v  The average yield was 190.67 loaves per bag.

v  Average production was 73.74 bags per day, this represents 91.02% of the target of 81 bags set.

v  Remixes noted were 1,406 pieces during the period

The table shows the summary findings of the mixing chart
attributes.recommendation:
The branch should strive to ensure that they attain their target.

The branch should work on remixes by adhering to the set production standard.
attributes.effect: The production target was not met, meaning the branch had some idle capacity resulting in unabsorbed fixed costs and other opportunity costs.

value:
Remixes were highly caused by frequent oven breakdown.

Production was affected by low sales
Remixes were caused by frequent breakdown (MBN 201 and MBN 226)

In prior audit production target was averaged at 161.96 bags per day.

The remixes were 5,574 tins
Previous
An analysis of both mixing chart and mixing chart summary were done for a period of 38 days from 1st March 2025 to 7th April 2025.
Production procedure were followed to the letter.
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to calculate the average yield, Utto consumption, checking for time lags as well as the presence and magnitude of remixes.

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
We found that cash at hand matched with book balance. The table below illustrates the findings: 

We also observed that there were two pending IOus, of Ksh.7,000.00. (Albert Okoth date 22.03.25 for meals, Ramadhan Ksh.5,000.00 for construction site inspection)
attributes.recommendation:
Maintain the cash handling controls.

Branch management should ensure IOUs are cleared within the set time.
attributes.effect:
Cash controls were adequate and efficient.

On of the IOU for Albert have been pending for 18 days which is against the policy of clearing IOUs within three days.

value: Cash controls are okay and will maintain the trend.
Albert Okoth was a storekeeper bought from Kisumu to oversee ongoing site construction and Accountability of Site materials and the ious will be cleared

In the prior audit it was noted that expected cash had a minimal positive variance of Kshs +2.

There was no outstanding IOU
Previous
Internal audit conducted unannounced cash count in the cash office on 10th April 2025.
The unannounced cash count conducted didn't found any significant discrepancies or irregularities. Internal controls related to cash handling appeared to be functioning effectively
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to ensure the accuracy of the financial records.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description: It was noted that the production efficiency was 4.33 bags per production worker, and the standard achieved was above the set limit. The table below illustrates the findings.
attributes.recommendation: The branch should work on production efficiency
attributes.effect: Failing to achieve production efficiency implies that the labour force was not fully utilized, and this resulted in an increase in cost

value: We will try to improve our targets to achieve the set target
Efficiency was affected by shift cut and breakdown of the ovens. However, we will push to achieve to set target.
In prior audit it was noted that the production efficiency was 4.45 bags per production worker
Previous
Production efficiency was calculated for a period of 38 days from 1st March 2025 to 7th April 2025
The audit revealed that branch didn't effectively and efficiently utilize the labour force.
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.50 bags.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description: From the calculation the average packing efficiency for the sample period was 80.81 crates per slicer as illustrated on the table below
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should work on packing efficiency by scheduling the right number of slices to match the amount of   work available in any given shift.
attributes.effect: The branch did not achieve the targeted slicing efficiency of 97 crates, resulting in an excess hiring of 73 slicers with cost implication of ksh. 66,576.00

value: Doing follow-up and training of newly recruited staff to ensure target achievement.
We will put more effort into achieving the set target.
It was noted that the average slicing efficiency for the period was 80.81 crates per slicer
Previous
Packing Efficiency was computed for a period of 38 days from 1st March 2025 to 7th April 2025.
Internal audit found that the branch did not effectively  and efficiently utilized labour force.
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to determine whether the set company standard of 97 crates per packer was being achieved

attributes.title: Vehicles fuel consumption analysis
attributes.description:
From the analysis it was found that all fuel consumption of all the vehicles was within the set standards except for KDK 287W.

The table below illustrates the finding: -
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should ensure that the generator consumption rate is within the recommended standards.
attributes.effect: Fuel overconsumption increases the fuel cost

value: To keep up the trend
To be maintained
In a prior audit report, the generator fuel consumption was 24.45 litres per hour
Previous
Analysis of fuel consumption was done for the month of March 2025.
Fuel controls in place were working effectively.
Operations/Production Department

The primary objectives were to evaluate compliance with fuel efficiency standards, identify any areas of inefficiency, and recommend strategies for reducing fuel consumption and associated costs. The audit encompassed a comprehensive review of fuel records, maintenance logs, and related policies and procedures.

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption
attributes.description: We noted that the generator was consuming 21.27 liters/hour. The consumption was within average mean consumption as per audit period as shown below.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should ensure that the generator consumption rate is within the recommended standards
attributes.effect: The generator consumption was well controlled

value: To keep up the trend
To be maintained
In a prior audit report, the generator fuel consumption was 24.45 litres per hour.
Previous
An analysis was done on the generator fuel consumption for a period of 40 days from 1st March 25 to 9th April 2025.
Generator fuel consumption was within the set standard.
Operations/Production Department
The aim was to establish if fuel consumption was within the set standard.

attributes.title: Analysis of the Oven breakdown.
attributes.description:
We found that the oven had been repaired 9 times, and 1,814 loaves were damaged and as a result the oven broke down.

Also, we noted that oven damages recorded on branch manager damages book was 2,020 loaves more by 206 pieces. This means this loaf was damaged but not captured on the job card.

A weakness was noted in the process of recording oven damages and stocking out. This exposes the company to loss.
attributes.recommendation:
Ovens need to be checked frequently to reduce breakdowns.

The operation manager should verify oven damages before raising good issue
attributes.effect: Oven breakdown has resulted in revenue loss

value: We are follow up with the KAF to ensure oven are operation efficiently

As Mentioned Already requested for replacement of MBN 226 oven to avoid losses.

Still following with KAF to reduce time
Internal audit verified job card to establish the frequency of the oven breakdown. For the period between 1st March 2025 to 9th April 2025
Oven were not operating effectively and efficiently
Operations/Production Department
To establish the frequency of the oven breakdown.
